channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Perl Developer and Business Owner? Remote Perl role in UK & EU
item.description: Our clients run a job search engine that has grown from two friends with an idea to a site that receives more than 10 million visits per month. They're looking for a Perl pro with at least three years of experience with high-volume and high-traffic apps and sites, a solid understanding of Object-Oriented Perl (perks if that knowledge includes Moose), SQL/MySQL and DBIx::Class.

item.title: C, C++, and Perl Software Engineers, Let’s Keep the Internet Safe
item.description: A leading digital safeguarding solutions provider is looking for a software engineer experienced in C, C++, or Perl. You’ll have strong Linux knowledge and a methodical approach to problem solving that you use to investigate, replicate, and address customer issues. Your keen understanding of firewalls, proxies, Iptables, Squid, VPNs/IPSec and HTTP(S) will be key to your success at this company.

item.title: Perl to Node Cross-training? Yes Please! UK Remote Perl Role
item.description: The client is interested in anyone with experience building web apps in Perl, using one of the major Perl frameworks. If you’re a crack-hand with Catalyst, a Mojolicious master, or a distinguished Dancer, they want you. You’ll be deploying apps your work to AWS, so experience would be handy, and the company’s big on testing, so they’d like you to know your way around Test::More.

item.title: Bold, beautiful, and… brainy? Senior Perl roles in Malaysia, Dubai and Malta
item.description: Our client provides online trading services and with offices in Dubai, Malta, and Malaysia, they’ve got the global reach that may provide the challenge you’re looking for. Their staff count has increased 600 percent in the last four years, and growth is still on the upswing. They know that a seasoned Perl pro is just what their team needs as they expand, and that’s where you come in.

item.title: 63 Corporations that share Open Source code
item.description: Since I posted this, I added a lot more corporations. Thanks to contribution of Dean Hamstead as well.

item.title: Day 9: CI for Mojo-UserAgent-Cached and Plack-Middleware-Greylist
How to install cpanm using HTTP::Tiny and Perl oneliner?
item.description: I am not sure it is really needed as Strawberry Perl for Windows, the only place where you don't have built in curl already comes with cpanm preinstalled. But nevertheless an interesting possibility.

item.title: Jumphost - Pull Switch Configs with Perl
Canadian Municipal GitHub Rankings
item.description: While looking for Open source projects I bumped into an interesting listing of government-related GitHub organizations.

item.title: How to create cpanfile by "perl Makefile.PL"?
item.description: An interesting possibility to se cpanfile with Makefile.PL

item.description:
Great CPAN modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: PWC 194
item.description: Blog post showing the porting of Perl solution to Raku and Julia. Plenty to learn every week.

item.title: Digital frequency
item.description: For both Perl and Python fans, have fun. Well done.

item.title: Digital Equaliser
item.description: Advise and suggestions in the blog post is worth checking. Thanks for sharing knowledge with us.

item.title: Completing the time and levelling the letters
item.description: Compact collection of various test cases. This makes the logic easy to follow. Keep it up great work.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 194
item.description: Once again we got the demo of PDL this week. Thanks for sharing the knowledge with us.

item.title: regular expressions everywhere!
item.description: Are you regex fan? If yes then this is for you. Thank you.

item.title: Digital Clock and Frequency Equalizer
item.description: Great demo of Perl and Raku with such an ease. Thanks for sharing knowledge with us.

item.title: iffy solutions
item.description: James introduced new term to me, IIFE. Thanks for your contributions every week.

item.title: PWC194 - Frequency Equalizer
item.description: The frank and open discussion is the highlight. Plenty to keep up busy every week.

item.title: PWC194 - Digital Clock
item.description: Flavio makes the task simple to follow. What a treat, thank you.

item.title: Freq Out, Man!
item.description: Deep task analysis is not to be missed. Highly recommended.

item.title: Bag Time!
item.description: I noticed sharp observations about the task. Good catch. Well done and keep it up great work.

item.title: Digital Frequalizer
item.description: Lots of Raku magic shared as every week. Plenty to keep you busy. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 194
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Digital Clock" and "Frequency Equalizer" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 195
item.description: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks: "Special Integers" and "Most Frequent Even". If you are new to the weekly challenge, why not join us and have fun every week? For more information, please read the FAQ.

item.title: Wake up! Time to open presents!
AoC 2022/7 - ENOSPC - no space left on device
AoC 2022/3 - Misplaced supplies and where to find them
RedBlack tree mockup in Corinna
item.description: Yves Orton wanted to see a complex class implemented in Corinna, so I mocked up a red-black tree.

item.title: Kephra: goto (last) edit
item.description: A very interesting topic about goto and very engaging article worth checking.

item.title: Good bye PrePAN
item.description: What a shame we lost PrePAN. It is too late to do anything, unfortunately.

item.title: This Week in PSC (090)
item.description: More regular updates by PSC team,

item.title: #594 - Advent Calendar
item.description:
Hi there,

The Advent Calendar celebration begins with the start of December. For all Perl fans, we have Perl Advent Calendar 2022, thanks to the hard work of Olaf Alders and his team. I am sure you have checked out the amazing daily source of fun.

As of today, we have got through 12 days.

Do you have any favourite so far?

Well I do have mine. To me the best part is the festive flavour in every article. I find it amusing and fun to read the story. I have contributed in the past but never got around to add the spice. I would blame the lack of background knowledge. This year's calendar started with Toby Inkster creation Silent Mite. What a cool way to start the calendar. If you look at closely all the contributions so far, you would notice a fresh air with lots of positive energy. One name stands out very prominently this year is Thibault DUPONCHELLE. His first contribution, Santa is on GitHub was a nice way to begin the journey. Then found a gem from a very dear friend of mine, Julien Fiegehenn talking about good old friend CGI. In fact, I have seen him presenting the subject northpole.cgi at the Perl Conference. I found another piece of work by Thibault DUPONCHELLE about MongoDB. I found the Day 5 contribution Catching dreams is worth checking, if you want to explore MongoDB. If I am not mistaken then few years ago, Dave Cross shared his creation SVG::ChristmasTree in Perl Advent Calendar. I was happy to see it part of this year calendar too, not directly though. Day 8 started with A Perlmas Tree by Maximilian Lika. I found Day 11 contribution very technical dealing with signal ALRM. Not an easy subject to discuss in the Advent Calendar in my humble opinion. Thanks OODLER for the fine contribution, Wake up! Time to open presents!.

If you are still looking for more Advent Calendar theme fun then I would highly recommend, The Weekly Challenge Advent Calendar. Like in the past, this year also, it has contributions from Team PWC hand picked by me. I am sure you would find it interesting.

I am working on something that I would love to be part of this year Perl Advent Calendar. Hopefully it would be ready soon. Well I am also working on something similar for Raku Advent Calendar. It would be an achievement if I can get both done on time. Please wish me luck.

Enjoy rest of the newsletter.
item.dc:subject: editorial
